info.game_comments:
2005 College Championship quarterfinal game 4.
From the RBC Center in Raleigh, North Carolina.

jeopardy_round: I KNOW WHAT YOU DID LAST SUMMER
double_jeopardy_round: WE'VE GOT MORE PEOPLE THAN YOU!

(2, 1).clue: The Woz, Steve Wozniak, built the first computer for this company

(3, 1).clue: In the 1840s he began reaping fame & fortune from the sale of his reaping machines

(4, 1).clue: A rocket scientist in training, you interned at this lab, JPL for short

(5, 1).clue: This Da Vinci masterpiece is a portrait of the second wife of a Florentine merchant

(6, 1).clue: On July 1, 2005 this school, Doug Flutie's alma mater, became the ACC's 12th member

(1, 2).clue: In New York:A brand of toothpaste

(2, 2).clue: Steve Ballmer has big geek shoes to fill for this Washington State software company

(3, 2).clue: In June 1876 George Custer made his last stand at the Battle of this river

(4, 2).clue: You worked with this group founded by Millard Fuller to help build homes for low-income families

(5, 2).clue: This mural depicts the reaction to Jesus' declaration that "one of you shall betray me"

(6, 2).clue: She's the ACC's all-time goals leader in women's soccer with 103

(1, 3).clue: In Texas:An edible grain of the Gramineae family

(2, 3).clue: This director's geek cred was sealed when he sold his film co.'s computer division & it later became Pixar

(3, 3).clue: It was the largest & most powerful state of the German Empire in the 1800s

(4, 3).clue: You worked as a "blended beverage technician" at this chain that started as The Juice Club in 1990

(5, 3).clue: Being left-handed made it easy for Leonardo to use what's called this type of writing named for a grooming aid

(6, 3).clue: You'll be a hell of an engineer if you graduate from this school, a 1990 champ in football

(1, 4).clue: In Massachusetts:Small clumps of hairs, trees or grass

(2, 4).clue: Sexy Linus Torvalds made us melt when he created this freely distributed UNIX clone in 1991

(3, 4).clue: Much of the fighting in this war, 1853 to 1856, took place on a peninsula in the Black Sea

(4, 4).clue: You went to summer school to take this branch of science that deals specifically with compounds of carbon

(5, 4).clue: Italy has issued euro coins with this Da Vinci "Man" on the reverse

(6, 4).clue: In 1954, when you talked about Arnold, you meant this Wake Forest golfer & ACC champ

(2, 5).clue: Hunky Marc Andreessen turned heads with this early web browser & company, later brought out by AOL

(3, 5).clue: In 1889 this South American country's last emperor, Pedro II, was forced to abdicate

(4, 5).clue: You slept til noon every day & read novels like "The Devil Wears Prada" & "Bergdorf" these

(5, 5).clue: Around 1485, Leonardo painted the young lady with this short-tailed weasel seen here

(6, 5).clue: The only ACC withdrawal came in 1971 when this university's Gamecocks resigned

(2, 1).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew gives the clue accompanied by a puppet at the Golden Theatre in New York: "I'm on the Broadway set of Avenue Q.")  This troubled character in "Avenue Q" has the same name as an Ivy League university in New Jersey--you do look preppy"Why thank you!"

(3, 1).clue: When beekeepers open an active hive, they blow this into it first

(4, 1).clue: This president lost Haynsworth & Carswell but won with Harry Blackmun in 1970

(5, 1).clue: Scrooge's 2-word response to "A merry Christmas, Uncle!"

(6, 1).clue: Draw & push the bellows so that air passes over the reeds to play this instrument

(2, 2).clue: Harvey Fierstein milked the role of Tevye in a revival of this classic musical

(3, 2).clue: Siberia is a source for this golden gem, November's birthstone

(4, 2).clue: When John Jay quit, John Rutledge failed to win confirmation as Chief Justice for this president

(5, 2).clue: After recanting is belief that the Earth orbits the sun, he's said to have muttered, "But it does move"

(6, 2).clue: Due in part to scandals at Enron & WorldCom, the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 sought to reform this profession

(2, 3).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew gives the clue suspended in a bubble in front of a giant clock in the Gershwin Theatre in New York.)  In the hit musical "Wicked", this beautiful resident of Oz floats in high above the set

(3, 3).clue: The languages of Mauritania include Soninke, French & this official one

(4, 3).clue: This president not only got Bork-ed but also got smoked with Douglas Ginsburg

(5, 3).clue: It's said William Booth sent his troops in this charitable "Army" a 1-word telegram: "Others!"

(2, 4).clue: Yes, "Sir": Robert Goulet played him in "Camelot" & Hank Azaria played him in "Spamalot"

(3, 4).clue: (Jeff Probst delivers the clue from Palau.)  Palau celebrates its independence on October 1st because it signed a compact with this country on that date in 1994

(4, 4).clue: In 1881 Stanley Matthews failed under Hayes but was confirmed under this doomed president

(5, 4).clue: French title of Zola's 1898 letter to President Faure

(6, 4).clue: When used as a catalyst to spread fire, gasoline is considered this

(2, 5).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew gives the clue from inside a giant tree in the New Amsterdam Theatre in New York.)  I'm here in the tree of this character, who's a male baboon in the movie & played by a female here on Broadway

(3, 5).clue: From the Latin for "pouch", it's the scientific term for a possum's pouch

(4, 5).clue: William Hornblower & Wheeler Peckham gave this president back-to-back losses in 1894

(5, 5).clue: The King James Bible's shortest verse, "Jesus wept", refers to the death of this man

(0, 0).clue: Launched in 2004, Billboard's first Top 20 chart for these included "My Boo", the "Halloween" theme & "Ice Ice Baby"
